title: Pence Asserts U.S. Support for Poland at Ceremony Marking Start of World War II
text:
WARSAW—Poland commemorated the 80th anniversary of the outbreak of World War II in a solemn ceremony in which Vice President Mike Pence asserted continued U.S. support for what the Trump administration has come to view as a reliable security ally.

Mr. Pence attended the military event—an important rite for Poland, which lost a fifth of its population during Nazi occupation—on Sunday after President Trump canceled his planned visit, citing Hurricane Dorian. Hours after Mr. Trump backed out, German Chancellor Angela Merkel said she would attend, joining German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier.

“America and Poland will continue to stand for our common defense,” Mr. Pence said. “America never gave up on the freedom and independence of the Polish people, and we never will.”

The ceremony offered the nationalist ruling party, Law and Justice, a chance to showcase its close ties to the White House before elections in October.

Mr. Pence visited Warsaw the same weekend as Energy Secretary Rick Perry and national-security adviser John Bolton. All spoke of strengthening the American ties with Poland and Europe’s eastern flank against Russia.

The Americans’ presence reflected the Trump administration’s view of Poland as an ally that is growing closer to Washington in a corner of Europe where U.S. influence is under strain from rival world powers. The U.S. has signed an agreement to add 1,000 troops to the contingent of roughly 4,500 currently kept in rotation in rural Poland. That military presence is meant to deter the Russian military from crossing into Poland or its Baltic neighbors.

Over the next few days, the U.S. hopes to sign an agreement with Poland aimed at protecting the security of the country’s telecommunications systems, a senior U.S. official said before the trip, a move that comes as U.S. officials pressure other allies to cut ties with Chinese telecommunications company Huawei Technologies Co. over national-security concerns.

The U.S. aims to block a pending Chinese acquisition of a helicopter manufacturer in Ukraine. On Saturday, Mr. Perry said the U.S. is looking to sell gas to Ukraine via Poland to help Kiev reduce energy dependence on Moscow.

“We expect Russia to be a good citizen, we expect them to respect the sovereignty of Ukraine,” he said. “The fact is, the United States has been pretty, pretty rough, pretty tough. We’ve hit them right in the nose a time or two to get their attention. And we will continue to do that.”

Mr. Pence asserted support for Ukraine during a meeting with President Volodymyr Zelensky on Sunday that Messrs. Perry and Bolton also attended. “We will continue to stand with the people of Ukraine on your security, on territorial integrity, including Ukraine’s rightful claim to Crimea.”

Mr Pence didn’t answer a question on the status of Ukraine security-assistance funds, which have been under review by the administration.

For his part, Mr. Zelensky thanked Mr. Pence, saying “we really appreciate the United States’ efforts defending the rights of Ukraine,” adding that he has spoken to Mr. Trump over the phone twice.

Supporters of President Trump in Warsaw on Sunday. Photo: Sean Gallup/Getty Images

Poland’s government is trying to mobilize its generally pro-American base to retain the majority it wields in Parliament. Mr. Trump is popular in Poland, and state media for more than a week ran glowing reports of what Mr. Trump’s visit would mean for the country. Signs and T-shirts backing Mr. Trump and the U.S. were spotted in the crowds at the ceremony.

Polish media speculated that Mr. Trump’s visit would pave the way for the U.S. to lift immigration restrictions that require Poles to get a visa to visit the U.S. When Mr. Trump canceled, opposition leaders and government critical media seized on it as a public embarrassment.

On Sunday afternoon, Mr. Trump told reporters he would like to come to Poland soon, following up on a 2017 visit.

“I just want to congratulate Poland,” he said when asked if he had a message for the country on the World War II anniversary. “It’s a great country with great people.”

Poland’s nationalist government has often cited World War II in an appeal to voters, insisting that Germany pay reparations. On Sunday morning, Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki repeated that demand.

The government has revised state museum exhibits and textbooks to elevate stories of Polish wartime heroism. It has sought to squelch what it views as the falsehood that Polish society deserves any blame for the Holocaust.

The government’s hawkish views on Russia have been reflected in its World War II commemorations: President Vladimir Putin wasn’t invited to Sunday’s event.

Russia’s Foreign Ministry said it was the Soviet Union that defeated Nazism and saved European democracy from destruction, in a post on its official page on Russian social-media website Vkontakte.

Ten years earlier, Mr. Putin attended the 70th anniversary and was praised for telling a Warsaw audience that the Soviet Union had been immoral in its brief alliance with Nazi Germany.

“Now I think the illusion is gone,” said Slawomir Debski, director of the Polish Institute of International Affairs. “We are in much different place than we used to be even 10 years ago.”
